comment.author: 88050711@N05
comment._content: My great grandmother lived in this Lane in 1871!

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88050711@N05] Wonderful! And a momentous year 1871 (Paris Commune etc.) Do you know which section of the lane she lived? It was quite a long little street, running from our viewpoint here on George Street, up several flights of stairs, past the Ocean Wave Hotel on Gloucester Street - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3810093259/]and past Cumberland Street - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/3810910116/] to Princes Street. The course of the lane can be followed in these maps. The second shows street numbers which may help you pinpoint precisely where your GG lived if you have an address. Note the orientation is different in both maps - north is to the left in the 1st and to the right in the 2nd - 1888 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367453.html 1890 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367458.html This particular section of Little Essex Street below the stairs was known as Brown Bear Lane (after a pub on the corner) until the 1880s when it was officially designated as an extension of Little Essex Street.
